Award.AwardTitle: Fabry-Perot Studies of Equatorial Thermospheric Dynamics and Composition, Part II
Award.AbstractNarration: The investigators will make measurements of thermospheric winds and temperatures with an improved imaging Fabry-Perot Interferometer at Arequipa, Peru. Aeronomic research in recent years has determined the equatorial thermosphere-ionosphere system to be a highly-structured environment in which the ion-neutral coupling plays a crucial role in the physical processes that occur. Knowledge of the thermospheric neutral wind and temperature fields is essential to the improved understanding of how these processes function. The Arequipa Fabry-Perot interferometer (FPI) has been operating for two decades. Recently, this instrument was upgraded to get a five-fold increase in wind and temperature precision as compared with previous observations. Included in this research effort are twilight spectral profile measurements of the 732 nm oxygen ion emission rate to determine the thermospheric atomic oxygen density at low-latitudes. A new operating mode will allow the determination of the divergence and vorticity of the neutral wind field. The divergence measurement would provide an estimate of the mean vertical wind with a precision believed to be ten times better than that provided by direct measurements. These measurements are important for achieving an improved understanding of the Midnight Temperature Maximum (MTM), which is a significant feature of the nighttime equatorial thermosphere created by the convergence and downwelling of air near midnight at low latitudes. Two additional science objectives would be to achieve thermospheric gravity wave observations within a common volume between Arequipa and Huancayo with a bistatic FPI observatory. These results would allow for the examination of the frequency of thermospheric gravity waves by searching for simultaneous fluctuations in zonal and meridional wind components as well as thermospheric temperature. The science objectives of the Arequipa and Huancayo FPI instruments are significantly enhanced by the coordinated and synergistic activity of both instruments working together and with the Jicamarca Radio Observatory. Clemson Physics undergraduate and graduate students as well as Peruvian students would be exposed to technical problems of a practical nature that will broaden their experience and introduce them to the practice of research at the cutting edge of optical technology. Valuable experience in the operations of unattended FPIs at remote sites would be gained that would assist future expansion of the global FPI observatory network, a highly desirable goal for space weather forecasting applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this award was in part to achieve an increased coverage of thermospheric dynamics in the central Peru region by adding to the existing Fabry-Perot interferometer (FPI) observatory located at Arequipa, Peru, two new observatories located at Jicamarca, Peru, and at Nazca, a village located near the Nazca signs in central Peru. This expansion, carried out in collaboration with the staff at the Jicamarca Radio Observatory, provided additonal coverage of the equatorial thermospheric dynamics through the Doppler shift measurements of the spectral profile of the [O] 630-nm emission.  This new approach would provide not only the means for achieving common volume observations but also the means to achieve the mapping of the wind field without any ambiguities regarding the production of the maps.  Previous work involving the use of observations from one FPI observatory was unable to determine the transverse wind gradient relative to the line-of-sight as only motion away or toward the observatory can be detected, and a somewhat questionable assumption about the behavior of the winds as a function of local time only had to be invoked.

In the mapping analysis the wind components u and v are expanded in a Taylor series and the first order and second order gradients are evaluated by using the Doppler shift observations for the three stations of 24 equal azimuthal spaced directions, which are indicated in Figure 1. The installation of the two new FPI sites took several years to achieve but excellent results featuring simultaneous observations for the three FPI sites became available in mid-June, 2013. These maps show indication of eastward winds during the night preceded by winds from the northwest direction in the evening period. During the midnight period these maps indicated modulation of the eastward winds with a weak northward flow caused by the semi-diurnal tidal wave and other higher order harmonics. This modulation is expected to become stronger near the equinox period (i.e., in March or September). An example of these maps is shown in Figure 2 of this report. Figure 3 presents a summary map generated by taking vertical cuts through each individual map and assembling all of these together.

    The overall purpose of this investigation was to explore how the changes in the equatorial wind dynamics of the thermosphere might have a relationship to the variability of the production of disturbed ionospheric plasma caused by the well-known Rayleigh-Taylor plasma instability.  The maps produced by this new approach developed in this award would help improve our understanding of the changes that occur from day to day, from season (winter) to season (equinox), and from solar minimum to solar maximum.
